												"Most people think that time is like a river, that flows swift and sure in one direction. But I have seen the face of time, and I can tell you, they are *wrong.* Time, is an ocean in a storm. You may wonder who I am, and why I say this. Sit down, and I will tell you a tale like none you have ever heard."And thus begins the game that defined my childhood. Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time feels more like a playable fairy tale than just a normal, run of the mill video game. You play as the titular Prince, a young, proud, IMPOSSIBLY AGILE warrior from Persia who, with his father's army, ransacks an Indian Palace and seizes the legendary treasures within to gift to the Sultan of Azad: An hourglass filled with the (also titular) Sands of Time, a mystical substance that can affect the flow of time itself, and a crystal Dagger of Time that can capture and channel the Sands. Ever prideful, the Prince is tricked into releasing the Sands of Time unto Azad, twisting and corrupting those without the Sands' complementary artifacts into mindless abominations.It is up to him, and Princess Farah, the daughter of the Maharajah, to undo his fatal mistake.This game is packed with entertaining combat and mind-bending puzzles set to a pleasant pseudo-Persian/Arabian/Indian soundtrack composed by the talented Stuart Chatwood. In addition, this game is arguably the one that popularized the use of parkour, which you will use to navigate the crumbling and booby-trapped Sultan's palace. And that isn't even all; to this *very day,* Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time *still* has the best time-manipulation physics in gaming of all time. Voicework for the Prince is done by Yuri Lowenthal. Yes, the same man who voices Ben Tennyson (Ben 10) and Sasuke Uchiha (Naruto). It might just be bias, but that honestly makes it better in my opinion. The character development is quite solid as well. The dialogue between the Prince and Farah is witty, funny, and nuanced, and due to the poor Prince not having anyone else to talk to when he and Farah get separated, the game is also filled with deep, ponderous, or funny and meta monologues on the Prince's behalf. The love story between the Prince and Farah is also well written, and you can't help but root for the duo.If you can handle the occasionally difficult Sand Creature battle, tricky parkour, annoying as hell Sand Scarabs and Vultures, conserving your Sands, avoiding having Farah repeatedly peg your a$$ with arrows in the middle of a fight in a tight corridor, and navigate a time-consuming puzzle involving axles while being screamed at by a Persian guard with a thick Scottish accent and *NO CONCEPT OF VOLUME CONTROL* then this game is definitely for you!This game has endured for me, and if the speedrunning community is anything to go by, then we're *still* discovering new things and new ways to play the game more than a decade after its initial release. For that reason, and because of the game's mastery of time-manipulation... and because of the general theme, this game most definitely DESERVES the "Test of Time" Steam Award!

Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one of the most successful revivals in gaming history, and it is well deserved for having done so. 												*Warning* possible spoilers aheadPros: +Excellent platforming based puzzles. These are usually pretty simple to work out once you realise most of them have only one path but when you consider how they work as a whole they are pretty ingenious and will challenge you're platforming skills and timing.+Great atmosphere and art direction. The Persian setting is unique and rarely done. Even in 2014 this game looks excellent. The character models haven't aged well but the environments have for sure.+Ability to rewind time and use it in battle is an excellent idea+First person view allows you to offset the terrible camera+Varied enemies force you to engage combat in different ways+The Prince. Although it happens infrequently, when the Prince does chime in it's usually something humorous and entertaining.Cons:-The camera is a pain whether you're doing platforming or you're in combat. During platforming the camera will frequently move into undesirable positions forcing you to guess what you're supposed to be doing next. In combat it does the same which quickly becomes tiresome when you're unable to see the enemy attacking you from behind. It also struggles hard when you're in tight spaces and the camera has to contend with walls :S-You're companion is kinda useless and it feels as if you're partnership is a one way deal. During platforming she will stand there and let you do all the work aside from when she has to go through a few cracks or pull a few triggers (to Ubisoft's credit they use this as a point of humour which is much appreciated). In combat she is the same. The AI refuses to move from a certain position unless you stray too far from her which means that when there are multiple enemies attacking her she is essentially a sitting duck which wouldn't be too bad but she has very low health. Oh and her arrows can harm you. She killed me once when I had one enemy left to kill and a number of times her arrow has hit me stunning me for a number of enemies to take away my remaining health. Her voice actor is also very poor.-Combat encounters take far too long on occasions. You would expect combat to last about a cpuple of minutes at the most but sometimes they take double that making those encounters tedious to go through.-Fall heights are deceptive. There are essentially 3 fall heights. Twice you're height which the prince can handle. 2-3 times you're height the Prince will lose a bit of health. Anything above 3 times you're height and the Prince will die. This becomes incredible frustrating when you have what appears to be a manageable fall and yet the prince cant take it. What would have been useful is a more lenient falling system where you took larger damage rather than outright dying for higher drops.-The story. It feels as though everything is rushed. You never get a chance at the beginning to digest what is actually going and then suddenly you're on this Grand Adventure. What's worse is that at no point aside from the end of the game is the story truly developed, which is a shame because the concept is excellent. There are points in which the subplot with you're companion is expanded but it feels so contrived especially since she is so damn unlikable.Misc thoughts:=You're companion would be far more likeable if she was controllable. Frequently during the game there are situations only she can deal with like crawl into narrow spaces etc. I stand by my point that she is still useless as you tend to do 95% of the work but being able to control her would have enabled more complex puzzles and allowed there to be more variedplatforming challenges if creative enough. In combat it would allow you to experience a different combat style and allow you to better position her to reduce damage if you were primarily going to play as the Prince. I belieev this would also help you better engage with her as a character (although thevoice acting is still terrible)=It would be nice to have a larger variety of sand based abilities to use.=Controller support on PC would have made the game much more easier to control but as it is it's still very much playable.Final thought:Get the game if you enjoy excellent platforming and puzzles but pass if you're buying it for excellent combat or story.

												The Sands of Time when it originally came out boasted some of the best graphics and fluid 3D animation in games.  By today's standard, the graphics still look great and animation is even more fluid with the advance of video card speed.  The platforming is well executed.  The levels can be massive at times and requires you to go through a maze of wall runs, jumps, and many other acrobatic maneuvers in order to reach your goal.  The game almost runs like each major room is a level and you need to reach its objective/goal in order to move on to the next level.  The action can feel rather repetitive, however, some of the enemies do require a different approach and strategy to take down and kill.  However, the game is well paced to keep the actions repetition from annoying the gameplay too much.  Overall though, the fight scenes are well choreographed and your character looks really cool in action.  The introduction of the Sands of Time and the knife that allows you to rewind time if you fall to your death or get killed in battle is a really cool gimmick that works and fits very well in this game.  The storyline is great, especially when you realize how the beginning and the end come together to completely understand the story.  This is a classic, just as much as the original 2D Prince of Persia is a classic as well.  If you've never played this game, you should do yourself a favor and pick this up and play it.

												I really wanted to enjoy this game and give it a good review. The Prince of Persia Trilogy are some of my favorite games of all time, and I enjoyed them quite a bit on both PS2 and the original Xbox. Also, PC generally tends to be the most backwards compatible platform out there, and really the place to go to in general for those of us with a bit of a nostalgia kick. I've been able to play the original Doom, the original Diablo, Quest for Glory 1, King's Quest 1 (remake), Dune 2, and countless other older games on my new computer (core i7 with SLI GTX 980s, 32 gb ram, and 5 ssds in a RAID on Windows 10) over the past year with little or no issues.There are far too many technical issues that ruin the experience here to make it worthwhile though. With having to set up resolutions outside of game to get it to even start to show up on modern monitors, a white out/fog glitch that makes it imposssible to see anything (and I mean anything, the prince, ground, walls, enemies all invisible), no real controller support, and the issues go on. Yes, most of the issues have solutions in the forums, and I probably would have been okay with one or two issues, but that there are so many. I have to go to too many different forum topics and edit ini files to get this game to the start of a playable state, makes it so I just can't recommend this version of it.If you want to play or replay this game, do yourself a favor and get the PS3 version off Playstation Network. It supports modern resolutions, widescreen, runs smoothly, and even supports active 3d if that's your thing. All with much less work than this version. I feel like if Ubisoft wants to continue selling this on steam, it needs warnigs about it's issues on the store page, or some serious patching love.

												OVERALL 9.6/10Prince of Persia: Sands of Time is a story rich action-adventure game. It was originally released for major platforms (at the time) in 2003. Age has only made this game more of a gem. For those who have played Prince of Persia games in the past, and even this one, I would definately reccomend this, it is worthy as one of your many games in your steam library. This game is vastly better than Prince of Persia: Forgotten Sands 2010. To all newcomers to the franchise, I believe that this is the best Prince of Persia game there is. It is perfectly priced as a cheap but reputable price: £6.99 (although I did buy this during a sale at 50% off, I would reccomend buying at its full price too).STORY 10/10The story is very immersive, you virtually become the Prince of Persia, as he parkours and fights is way through the palace. The well written story and script adds to the characters' personalities and emotions. As the Prince's emotions grew, I became more empathetic of his lonliness and suspicions. It took me approximately 7 hours and 30 mins to complete, it will keep you hooked towards the end where the story becomes more intense and close to an end. For a game of its time, this is HUGE. It definately will take many sittings to complete, as it has many save points to allow you to save and "Continue my story from here..."GAMEPLAY 10/10Superbly varied and stylish combat, enemies become progressively harder, but base mechanics still apply. Few minor glitches do occur rarley however. Smooth mechanics of using 'The Sands' to travel through time to correct errors. Movement is fluent and fun, especially when doing parkour puzzles, and backflips during combat. The graphics are very ahead of its time, and there are some colossal areas to explore and mount during the game.PORT 9/10Runs like a dream, I had no problems running this on Win 8 and Win 10. I would drop it a point due to its lack of (1st party) Xbox One controller support, but using keyboard+mouse was seemless and after the first 30 mins of play feels natural and intended. Using keyboard does cause minor ♥♥♥♥-ups during parkour, but its nothing to ruin the experience.

												Prince of Persia is an old game. That much is obvious. However it is more than worth it. The first to bring up the idea of rewinding time to fix your mistakes in parkouring instead of killing you instantly. Like plenty of platforming games of its' time a single mistake would normally send you to a quick death. With the time mechanics of PoP if you have the available resources you can go back and fix those mistakes. The combat is simple yet satisfying when you survive a horde of sand monsters. With a unique health recovery system of drinking water stumbling upon a basin of water or pool is like finding an oasis in the desert. While Prince of Persia is a classic game it has a few problems. The biggest one is sometimes the controls don't work too well on a mouse and keyboard. With the health system you can go a long time with low health and end up suffering a few frustrating deaths multiple times. There are also a few enemies that are lackluster (crows, scarabs) that get annoying. This is compounded by a short animation that plays of your character putting his weapons away that you can't skip. The last con is that save points have you seeing a vision of a possible future. While it is a neat way of giving you hints there are far too many that are close to each other. To sum it up Prince of Persia is the start of a good series that hit a home run despite the few problems it has. If you want a classic platformer this is the game for you with crazy contraptions and fun applications of platforming. This game is plenty of fun.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Just to make one thing very clear right from the start: This game was one of my first full 3d games (besides Prince of Persia 3d, actually, but well, we all know how that game looked), and actually was one of my first very own games. Got it for my 8th birthday, and it took me forever to finish it because I was really bad at games and was scared of the sand monsters. Naturally, with a history like this, I am deeply, DEEPLY biased towards this game, so you should probably take my review of it with a huuuuuuge grain of salt.Well, with that out of the way, let's begin, eh?Just some fyi history for those interested:This game is actually the fourth in a series that started back in 1989. The original game was a 2d sidescrolling-ish platformer-ish based entirely of (for its time) realistic movement and 1v1 sword duels. It was a pretty big success, and it spawned two sequels. The first one was just like the original in design, just better looking, longer and more cryptic. I haven't beaten it without cheats to this day, and especially the last level is very unintuitive, though also very memorable.Sadly, the third game was made in a time where EVERYTHING had to go 3d. Though originally intended as a 2d game just like its predecessors, it was ground through the 3d meatwolf. Though I personally loved it, it wasn't a big success (understandably so), and the series went dead for a few years. Eventually, Ubisoft got the rights, and with the help of the original developer Jordan Mechner, they created a new Prince of Persia game, with a new character, and a semi-new setting (it's still Persia obviously, just somewhere else in Persia).So what's the story? A young persian prince is riding with his dad, the king of Persia, to conquer and raid an indian palace. With the help of a traitor on the inside (an evil vizier, what a shocker), they get through the gates and storm the palace. The prince gets into the (unrealistically huge) treasure chamber, where two mysterious and powerful artifacts are housed: The hourglass, and the dagger of time. The prince claims the dagger for himself, and the persian army moves on to the kingdom of Azhat (Azat? Ahza... I don't even know if it's a real place, something like that anyway), where the evil vizier tricks the prince into ramming the dagger into the hourglass. That wasn't such a great idea, as it turns out, as the magical sand blasts out of the hourglass, ruining the palace and corrupting all living things inside, turning them into immortal zombies. No matter how many times you strike them down, they just pop back up. Unless the prince rams his dagger into their bellies and sucks the sand out of them, then they die for good. So now it's on: the prince and Farah, the daughter of the indian Maharaja, team up to fix the terrible mess that was caused. You spend a lot of time around Farah actually, and she is a very great character to be around. Helping you out in battle with her bow and arrow, crawling though creaks too small for the bulky prince, helping him solve puzzles, and being an allaround believable and likable character. She's one of the few companion characters done right, and I say that even though you sometimes have to protect her during battle, which is, as we are all aware, the worst thing in gaming. The game builds a very nice atmosphere too; it's just you and Farah in a ruined, but still beautiful world. Moonlit gardens, waterfilled caverns with flickering reflections, great halls and massive towers; the architectural design is as unbelievable as it can get, but it never takes you out of the moment since the game oviously has no pretends of being realistic; it's a fairy tale, 1001 night with time zombies, and even to this day, it's a beautiful looking game.Gameplay is pretty fun, though the games following after it improved on the combat, it's still very solid. You swing your sword, you block, you counter, you can do some fancy jump maneuvers over enemies heads and off of walls. Most uniquely though, you can wind back time for a bit using your dagger, That technique is equally useful during combat as it is during platforming. You don't have to start back at the checkpoint every single time you die that way, which is really nice. Also, you can slow down time during combat, or freeze an enemy in place and then chop it to dust; ooor you can unleash a very strange finishing move where all the enemies get frozen and you zhip around between them, chopping em all up. It's nothing too special, but it's entertaining nonetheless.So that's about all I can say about the game without giving the story away. As it stands, the only real problem I have with the steam release is that the ingame steam overlay doesn't work. But here's the strangest part: when I installed the game off the old disc version I still had lying around, and added it as a non-steam game, the overlay worked fine. What's up with that? I would've just stuck with that technique, but then I had to leave the disc in the drive the entire time, which is annoying. So I don't know what's up with that bug; it's not too bad, but I wish it wasn't there.TL;DRPros:-great story-amazing fairytale-esque atmosphere-likable and unforgettable characters-goodcontrols-solid and fun gameplay and combat-rewind mechanic makes platforming a lot less frustrating-the game still looks beautiful to this dayCons:-steam overlay doesn't work ingame for no real reasonNostalgia overload/10

												Surprisingly enough in this day and age the king of the early 2000s generation of games has aged quite decently, decently enough to be considerably better than other (probably most) 3D platformers currently out in the market. Price of Persia: The Sands of Time has a completely different formula from many other games you will play, it is still difficult to find games with new mechanics as intuitive as the time mechanics in this game back when it introduced them. It made platforming and puzzles funner despite being brutal without this mechanic, and the story created around this mechanic is absolutely amazing. The setpieces set in ancient Persia are absolutely gorgeous, and you are going to climb through all of them, even the furthest mighty tower is a tower you will platform through and feel like an absolute badass. Not only that, but you actually have a legitimate reason within the story to be going through all these setpieces, having a naive yet skillful prince grow as his journey continues with probably the best supporting character ever, who has one of the funniest yet completely natural relationships with our heroic prince. It all feels organic, you feel like a badass and you have all the right to. The only bits where the game manages to dwindle on it's greatness are a few bits of combat that drag out for way too long, but even then, it is most likely followed by an amazing platforming section and story bit that will make you forget it completely. This game was a legend and still is, buy it, at any given price buy it, because I can guarantee that you will never have such an amazing experience that feels new and interesting as you will with this marvel.

Posted: November 7, 2015
												Just to make one thing very clear right from the start: This game was one of my first full 3d games (besides Prince of Persia 3d, actually, but well, we all know how that game looked), and actually was one of my first very own games. Got it for my 8th birthday, and it took me forever to finish it because I was really bad at games and was scared of the sand monsters. Naturally, with a history like this, I am deeply, DEEPLY biased towards this game, so you should probably take my review of it with a huuuuuuge grain of salt.Well, with that out of the way, let's begin, eh?Just some fyi history for those interested:This game is actually the fourth in a series that started back in 1989. The original game was a 2d sidescrolling-ish platformer-ish based entirely of (for its time) realistic movement and 1v1 sword duels. It was a pretty big success, and it spawned two sequels. The first one was just like the original in design, just better looking, longer and more cryptic. I haven't beaten it without cheats to this day, and especially the last level is very unintuitive, though also very memorable.Sadly, the third game was made in a time where EVERYTHING had to go 3d. Though originally intended as a 2d game just like its predecessors, it was ground through the 3d meatwolf. Though I personally loved it, it wasn't a big success (understandably so), and the series went dead for a few years. Eventually, Ubisoft got the rights, and with the help of the original developer Jordan Mechner, they created a new Prince of Persia game, with a new character, and a semi-new setting (it's still Persia obviously, just somewhere else in Persia).So what's the story? A young persian prince is riding with his dad, the king of Persia, to conquer and raid an indian palace. With the help of a traitor on the inside (an evil vizier, what a shocker), they get through the gates and storm the palace. The prince gets into the (unrealistically huge) treasure chamber, where two mysterious and powerful artifacts are housed: The hourglass, and the dagger of time. The prince claims the dagger for himself, and the persian army moves on to the kingdom of Azhat (Azat? Ahza... I don't even know if it's a real place, something like that anyway), where the evil vizier tricks the prince into ramming the dagger into the hourglass. That wasn't such a great idea, as it turns out, as the magical sand blasts out of the hourglass, ruining the palace and corrupting all living things inside, turning them into immortal zombies. No matter how many times you strike them down, they just pop back up. Unless the prince rams his dagger into their bellies and sucks the sand out of them, then they die for good. So now it's on: the prince and Farah, the daughter of the indian Maharaja, team up to fix the terrible mess that was caused. You spend a lot of time around Farah actually, and she is a very great character to be around. Helping you out in battle with her bow and arrow, crawling though creaks too small for the bulky prince, helping him solve puzzles, and being an allaround believable and likable character. She's one of the few companion characters done right, and I say that even though you sometimes have to protect her during battle, which is, as we are all aware, the worst thing in gaming. The game builds a very nice atmosphere too; it's just you and Farah in a ruined, but still beautiful world. Moonlit gardens, waterfilled caverns with flickering reflections, great halls and massive towers; the architectural design is as unbelievable as it can get, but it never takes you out of the moment since the game oviously has no pretends of being realistic; it's a fairy tale, 1001 night with time zombies, and even to this day, it's a beautiful looking game.Gameplay is pretty fun, though the games following after it improved on the combat, it's still very solid. You swing your sword, you block, you counter, you can do some fancy jump maneuvers over enemies heads and off of walls. Most uniquely though, you can wind back time for a bit using your dagger, That technique is equally useful during combat as it is during platforming. You don't have to start back at the checkpoint every single time you die that way, which is really nice. Also, you can slow down time during combat, or freeze an enemy in place and then chop it to dust; ooor you can unleash a very strange finishing move where all the enemies get frozen and you zhip around between them, chopping em all up. It's nothing too special, but it's entertaining nonetheless.So that's about all I can say about the game without giving the story away. As it stands, the only real problem I have with the steam release is that the ingame steam overlay doesn't work. But here's the strangest part: when I installed the game off the old disc version I still had lying around, and added it as a non-steam game, the overlay worked fine. What's up with that? I would've just stuck with that technique, but then I had to leave the disc in the drive the entire time, which is annoying. So I don't know what's up with that bug; it's not too bad, but I wish it wasn't there.TL;DRPros:-great story-amazing fairytale-esque atmosphere-likable and unforgettable characters-goodcontrols-solid and fun gameplay and combat-rewind mechanic makes platforming a lot less frustrating-the game still looks beautiful to this dayCons:-steam overlay doesn't work ingame for no real reasonNostalgia overload/10

SoT still has great level design, an interesting although simple story and platforming that holds up really well. It's not all good though, there are two glaring issues one being an awful camera and the other being some of the most tedious combat you'll ever experience.  The fighting is extremely simplistic and not all that hard; but they will spawn upwards of 20 enemies to fight through in spots which really drags down the pacing of the game.  As for the camera, I'm using a widescreen patch and playing at 1920 x 1080, so I'm not sure if there is some bugginess with my setup; but I've found the camera to be really hard to orient, especially during fights.  It'll often get stuck behind scenery or zoom in too close. 												Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one of the great classics, and it is that for a reason. Aside from the compelling plot and memorable characters, Sands of Time features some of the best puzzle-platforming you'll find in any game. Fluid acrobatics across the rafters of ornate palace rooms and along the sides of immense towers combine with the perfect safety mechanism - the ability to briefly rewind time and undo that disastrous jump or ill-timed leap into a rotating saw blade. The rewind ability is limited in use so that it doesn't become a crutch or make things too easy, but remains effective at helping to curb the frustration that would result from, for instance, a single mistake at the very end of a run of successes. Combined with the brilliant and challenging level design, intuitive controls, and enough hidden secrets to make it worth playing over again, Sands of Time is an extremely satisfying game.

												To start: I used to add a header to these reviews, but since it often made the review too long to sumbit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery page.Gameplay: Sid Meier has a development mantra he calls the "Covert Action Rule," which goes, "It's better to have one good game than two great games." While this isn't necessarily a perfect way to continue into this game, it's the best one I've thought of. Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time is one you probably already know about. If you don't, then what you should know is that this game is half parkour simulator and half sword-fighting game; the latter of which I found to be incredibly infuriating at times, but I'll talk about that part later.The platforming in this game is really, really fun. There's a slight bit of puzzle to the platforming sections, but usually never to the point where you've gotta stop for a minute or two to think about how you're gonna tackle these jumps. Those are saved for the actual puzzles in the game, of which there are about five puzzle areas. The first one is of the highest quality in my opinion, but that's not to say that the later ones are bad; it's just that the first one is really well-designed. As far as the controls go, there's essentially a "magic parkour button," (you should definitely use a controller for this game, by the way) and most of the actions are done automatically. This can lead you to throw yourself off of a ledge more than a few times when you're starting out, but thankfully you've got the ability to rewind time once you get the Dagger of Time.This brings me to the combat, which I feel is both far too simple and far too complex. It's far too complex, since there are apparently 50+ combos that you can do in the game, of which I only ever really needed one (attack attack attack attack etc.), and there is no documentation in-game for the combos. That's not to say that having combos are a bad thing; I'd just like to know what they are. The game does no tutorializing as far as combos go, and in fact I only learned about this vast number of combos because I looked it up. This is one of the main reasons why the game can be very frustrating; I'm assuming that these combos are in the manual or something, but the Steam version doesn't come with a manual. Even then, the combos really should be in game in a menu somewhere. Also, there were many times in which I found myself stuck on the ground and unable to get up. It turns out that if you are blocking while you're on the ground, you can't get up. The game doesn't tell you about this either. Another reason why the game is too complex for its own good is that there's only about six different types of enemies throughout the entire game, and they all pretty much have the same AI pattern of "surround player, stunlock to death," which sure does suck whenever your  only real way of getting out of that situation is jumping over enemies, and the type of enemy surrounding you are ones that can't be jumped over.The game is also far too simple, partly because of one major sin: automatic lock-on. If you are even pointing your analog stick in the directon of the enemy, you'll magically be attracted to that enemy for a while, even if you're pointing away from them. It's really annoying, and can lead to many times of getting surrounded. Trying to roll through a tight gap to avoid getting surrounded by un-jumpable enemies? Too bad; you're jumping on the un-jumpable enemy. Trying to attack a once faraway enemy that you're getting closer to? You will if you get lucky enough that the Prince stops ogling at an enemy you were attacking prior. Even beyond the frustrating bits with the controls, there's the fact that every single enemy is defeated in the same way: attack until they fall on their stomach, use the dagger to absorb them. Also yes, if you were wondering, the lock-on can mess you up with this as well, leading you to use powerups on enemies you didn't want to when you were just trying to absorb some sand.And then there's your game-long escort, Farah. Notice how I said escort and not partner? Intentional. She's an absolute idiot in combat. She comes with a bow, but constantly insists on standing statuesque directly in the fray, even when being attacked, when a much simpler solution would be for her to get to some dang high ground. There's loads of it around, so there's really no excuse for it. Also, if she dies, the game is over. What does she offer to the game as a whole? The ability to crawl through small gaps. Yes, in the grand scheme of things, she's about as useful as a puppy, mouse, or other small animal. She's about as useful in combat as well, actually. You see, she can't actually kill enemies. She just stuns them every now and then when she's not looking around in random directions admiring the architecture as though the idea of stone buildings is the most amazing thing ever. Long story short, she's absolutely useless and is more of a liablility than anything else.Speaking of the architecture (and something positive), the level design is fantastic. I'll go more into detail in the graphics section, but for now, I can definitely say that they did an excellent job creating a world that feels natural for the most part. There are a few pretty contrived places here and there, but who knows what those crazy architects are up to anymore, eh? Apart from that, though, that's all I really have to say about this game's gameplay. The platforming is super fun, but the combat just really brings the game down in my opinion. Then again, maybe games like Metal Gear Rising, Bayonetta, and Devil May Cry 1 have led me to expect too much from these kinds of games. I still stand with what I said at the beginning; this game would be so much better if it were two games: a game focused almost entirely on platforming with maybe 5% of the game being combat, and another game being 95% combat (with a more-developed combat system/enemy variety) and 5% platforming. As is, you've got one really good thing and one really frustrating thing which kinda makes me not wanna play this game again. If it weren't for the combat, this game would easily get a 10/10 from me, but with the combat, it drops to a 7/10. Great at times; absolutely miserable at others.Story: You may have gathered from that one paragraph that I don't like Farah all that much. You'd be right. To be honest, it still doesn't really make sense why she comes along at all; she's useful for being small and that's about it. All this being said though, she's not a badly written character; just an okay one. She is a love interest of the Prince, which again feels pretty contrived to me, and to be quite frank; I think the Prince is insane for wanting her. Oh well; I couldn't possibly hope to understand what goes through the Prince's head. As for the prince itself, he's pretty much straddling the line between hero and anti-hero. He wants to do good, but he's a bit of a selfish prat at the same time. Then again, he *is* a prince, so you can't expect him to have had the greatest socialization experience growing up, so fair enough. Apart from Farah and the Prince, everyone else is just a minor character. The premise and delivery is pretty cool, too; it's being told in terms of a story, and as such, has the ablility to go back and forth, as does happen with the story and the gameplay. It's all quite clever, I must admit. While the character arcs may not be the most amazing thing ever, I can appreciate the clever nature of the delivery and the premise enough to give it an 8/10.(I actually have run out of space; time to put the rest in the comments again!)

												As one who has played this game way back around 2003, I found it a very nostalgic experience.  After reviewing other reviews, both the good and the bad, I have come to a fair conclusion:Most people think this game is amazing, due to nostalgia, or hate it because they felt that the nostalgic audience were completely wrong.  In my opinion, I think the game good, not exellent or fantasic, but just good.  (8/10)Why is this?  Well, going over the facts, nostalgia, although present in my opinion, is not the entirity of it.  There a few glitches here and there, most of which wont be found unless you play like I do.  Nothing too game breaking either.  The camera, which many complain is very bad is actually extremely good most of the time.  If you are right in the center of combat, especially with bird enemies, it starts spinning out of control, but it is still managable.  Most jumps may have "difficult" camera angles until you realise that most are marked with shadows or moss.  The game, although seeming easy at first, escalates throughout the story at a decent rate.  This being an old classic, does have great graphics for its time, although some do seem a little lazy as well.  Most of the animations are smooth as well, although if you are playing for animations rather than the puzzles and combat, I would suggest a game that is made a little later than 2003.  The story may seem a little short, but is executed well and is great considering the limitations of console memory back in the day.  Lastly, the soundtrack and effects are executed quite well throughout the game.All in all, this game is overrated by most who have replayed it and underrated by the ones who chalk up hating the game because "it is only for nostalgic people."  I think it desires an 8/10 considering that it is relatively functional and has a great story and system of play behind it. I highly recommend a controller, since this was originally a console game.  I am guessing that some of the people who hated either didnt take the time to lay out a gamepad (controller) or didn't have one.  If you dont have one, this game may seem more of a 5 to 7/10.To finally conclude after such a long rant, it is a classic that recieves mixed ratings that are mostly bias and uncritical. Dont drop it the second things dont go your way, that is what is suppose to happen in game in the first place!My final and official rating: 8/10

												The story is presented as a tale being told by the prince.The Prince is tricked into unleashing the sands of time, turning everyone except the Prince and Farah into sand creatures, also unlocking the ability to alter time itself with the dagger of time. This is the games main gimmick. And it's a fun one, using his powers the prince must undo the damage he's done, aided by his AI companion Princess Farah. She's a capable partner in the many different puzzles and combat sections. And the Princes love interest. The pair have excellent chemistry and it does a lot for the games story. And the ending is still pretty good. It's not revolutionary. But it was a satisfying enough conclusion for me.The game runs like a dream. It didn't crash a single time for me. There are 3 tweaks to enhance the graphics. A widescreen patch, and forced anti-aliasing and anisotropic filtering. And one fix for a commmon issue on modern hardware.Now texture quality is about as consistent as the aim of a stormtrooper with alcoholism, having some of the all time muddiest looking textures I've ever seen and a few very sharp ones that aged well. Some of the glow and particle effects still look pretty good. Water has a wierd pixellation that's awful to look at. Each area is very unique and detailed. The textures might look like♥♥♥♥♥but you can see what they were going for. And it's beautiful. The two characters animations are solid. The amount of detail on the prince is downright impressive. Most of the enemies still look very good. Their animations telegraph certain incoming attacks and despite each enemy type being only a copy of it itself, I feel like these aged just fine. Creatures like beatles and birds still look pretty good.I'm terrible at judging sound and voice quality. But generally I had no problem believing the two main characters as they delivered their lines. The rest of the sound does a decent job with all of the sound effects being believable for me.The music is great.. but I didn't feel like it was used enough. Sometimes the absence of music is a good thing, but here it just feels strange. I found myself wondering if I was having a bug with the music not playing. When you do hear it, mostly during combat, it's exciting and I enjoyed each track. They all fit their moments pretty well for me.The Prince can run on walls, jump across pits filled with spikes, and climb crumbling ledges to traverse the enviroment. This is the games greatest strength as it throws platforming puzzles, traps and sometimes flying enemies at the player while you're climbing. The platforming sections feel very rewarding, and each one is a thrill to complete.Combat is fast paced and controls are handled well. Balacing when its right to strike, block, dodge or use the dagger to kill enemies who are knocked down. The game usually throws packs of different enemies at you at once all with different strengths and weaknesses to keep the experience from getting stale, Unfortunately it ends up being hindered by overstaying it's welcome. Almost every fight goes on a longer than it needs to and the combat began to feel repetitive because of this. I found myself just wanting to get back to the next platforming section halfway through each fight. You do get one ability that helps with mitigate this a little, but it isn't enough.There isn't really replayability here. After you've finished the game you won't have the desire to play it again. At least not for a while.The controls themselves still work great. And you'll get used them quickly. All of the controls can be rebound, but I didn't feel like I needed to. Platforming and Combat feels good, responsive and smooth as long as the camera is cooperating.Is it still fun? Yes. Absolutely. It's a blast. Thanks to it's fantastic platforming, solid puzzles, interesting story and characters and excellent soundtrack. It manages to not get dragged down by its faults. In many ways it is showing it's age. But after 13 years I have to say Prince of Persia : Sands of Time still holds up.My video review :
